items.body:
@damianmarti I noticed the bug on the state because the ETH/USD price indicator on the footer wasn't working on page load.

Before it was:
```ts
state.ethPriceSlice.ethPrice = newValue;
return state;
```

This is keeping the same object (newObj === oldObj) so it wasn't triggering a re-rendering.

I also tried the merging (returning only the changed stuff) but it's not working because of the way we are organizing the slices (each slide it's inside their own object prop).

Check out the Zustand documentation:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2486142/207398482-0d4afbd9-1be2-4dd1-814f-9ef2b3c9c175.png)


https://github.com/pmndrs/zustand/blob/main/docs/guides/updating-state.md#normal-approach

They offer some other solutions (which implies installing other libs). That's why I went with this approach. We could also refactor our slices:

From
```ts
export const useAppStore = create<TAppStore>()((...set) => ({
  tempSlice: createTempSlice(...set),
  ethPriceSlice: createEthPriceSlice(...set),
}));
```

To
```ts
export const useAppStore = create<TAppStore>()((...set) => ({
  ...createTempSlice(...set),
  ...createEthPriceSlice(...set),
}));
```

This way, everything would be at the same level and we could take advantage of the merging.

```ts
  setEthPrice: (newValue: number): void => set((state): TAppStore => ({ ethPrice: newValue })),
```

Or maybe I'm missing something... What do you think?

**Answer 1**
Right now on `scaffold.config.ts`:
```ts
const scaffoldConfig: ScaffoldConfig = {
  // ....
  deployerPrivateKey:
    "0xac0974bec39a17e36ba4a6b4d238ff944bacb478cbed5efcae784d7bf4f2ff80",

} as const;
```

```ts
const scaffoldConfig: ScaffoldConfig = {
  // ....
  deployerPrivateKey: process.env.deployerPrivateKey || 
    "0xac0974bec39a17e36ba4a6b4d238ff944bacb478cbed5efcae784d7bf4f2ff80",
 // ..
} as const;
```

Hey @technophile-04! Thank you so much for the write-up & context. Now I see everything more clearly. Some of the stuff you mentioned was on my notes (I was planning to post it in the pnpm PR, but will do it here)

I had a wall of text haha, but since you already did a great job given all the context, let me just comment on it and propose next steps.

> main issue : "Version mismatch between the local & prod env" i.e. https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/issues/419

Exactly. This is the most critical issue. We thought that having separate lock files would fix it (which it will!), but It was weird to me that not so many people were using that feature (and is not present in other package managers) & it seemed a bit unstable.

This PR fixes the issue (you are 100% right, it's not an issue when connecting repo in Vercel UI) in a better way :rocket: 

### CLI

> Locking versions in package.json makes sense there since we don't have .lock files and up for it  (We already using ~ their instead of ^)
> Not sure about adding .lock files by default. I mean currently its fine because we just have plain SE-2  next but when add extensions like TheGrpah then we will be needing to add more packages to plain SE-2 next which might not be easy

Thanks for the investigation @technophile-04 !

Some more stuff that I found (`yarn why` is great): 

This is the **CLI**:
![image](https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/assets/2486142/29218295-3b01-4ff1-b456-6cd476f99fdf)

This is **main**:

In CLI we have 2 diff versions because:
- newer version of the VERCEL package (28.15.1 => 28.15.7)
- newer version of types/react-copy-to-clipboard (5.0.4 => 5.0.5)

These two use a newer version of types/react (18.2.24).

-----

What I did then is to remove the `~` in the package.json file (only for next), so it installs the same version as in the lockfile (at least the top dependency!):

![image](https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/assets/2486142/706f3316-1bf9-4b35-b85c-34c815abe601)

```
    },
```

:cry: 

----

So not having a lockfile is tricky.

We can remove `~`, but things can always break in the future because a new release of sub-dependency updates and breaks something.

A decent solution:
- Remove `~`
- Have some kind of automated testing that runs every day, installs SE-2 with different options, runs some commands, and checks errors. That way we can identify issues early.

Not ideal, but better than nothing.

Thoughts?
